For example, the average annual growth rate in telephone calls averaged over 6 per cent during the 1970s, declined somewhat in the early 1980s, but had returned to 6 per cent by 1984.

Section 3(2)(b) Telecommunications Act 1984. This is one of several subsidiary objectives listed in Section 3. These include: to promote the interests of consumers; to promote efficiency and economy; to promote research; to encourage overseas companies that are major télécoms users to locate business in the UK and to promote abroad the interests of UK télécoms firms producing services or equipment.
To this end the DGTel may make orders to comply with licence conditions, enforceable by civil proceedings in court (Section 16).

One way in which the link between promoting the social objectives of universal service and restricting competition could have been broken is through the introduction of explicit external subsidy. The 1984 Act makes some provision for this. Section 93 provides for grants to promote the interests of disabled persons and Section 97 for local authorities to make payments to public operators towards 'losses' sustained in providing services. However, it is unlikely that these grants will replace the more important source of funding, cross-subsidy.

There may be circumstances in which exclusivity promotes innovation in much the same way as a patent. A general prohibition subject to approval by OFTEL on a case by case basis might therefore be the preferred policy.

The important point here is not that Mitel's share of the total PBX market was relatively small — 18 per cent in 1984; rather, that because the embryonic independent sources of distribution were themselves small, Mitel provided an important share of their sales.
